nodes.full_title: A Tool for Improving Privacy through Enterprise Risk Management
nodes.purpose: Enable better privacy engineering practices that support privacy by design concepts
nodes.name: NIST Privacy Framework 1.0

nodes.key_activities: Implement data protection, access control, security safeguards
nodes.function_definition: Develop and implement appropriate data processing safeguards

nodes.category_description: Technical security solutions are managed to ensure the security and resilience of systems/products/services

nodes.subcategory_name: Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations.
Communications and control networks are protected.
The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities.
Removable media is protected and its use restricted according to policy.

nodes.category_description: System maintenance and repairs are performed consistent with policies, processes, and procedures

nodes.subcategory_name: Remote maintenance of organizational assets is approved, logged, and performed in a manner that prevents unauthorized access.
Maintenance and repair of organizational assets are performed and logged, with approved and controlled tools.

nodes.category_description: Data are managed consistent with the organizations risk strategy to protect individuals privacy and maintain data confidentiality, integrity, and availability

nodes.subcategory_name: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify hardware integrity.
The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment.
Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity.
Protections against data leaks are implemented.
Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained.
Systems/products/services and associated data are formally managed throughout removal, transfers, and disposition.
Data-in-transit are protected.
Data-at-rest are protected.

nodes.category_description: Access to data and devices is limited to authorized individuals, processes, and devices
nodes.category_name: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control

nodes.subcategory_type: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
nodes.subcategory_name: Individuals and devices are proofed and bound to credentials, and authenticated commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals� security and privacy risks and other organizational risks).

nodes.subcategory_type: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
nodes.subcategory_name: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation).

nodes.subcategory_type: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
nodes.subcategory_name: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties.

nodes.subcategory_type: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
nodes.subcategory_name: Remote access is managed.

nodes.subcategory_type: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
nodes.subcategory_name: Physical access to data and devices is managed.

nodes.subcategory_type: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
nodes.subcategory_name: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized individuals, processes, and devices.

nodes.category_description: Security and privacy policies, processes, and procedures maintained and used to manage the protection of data
nodes.category_name: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Privacy procedures are included in human resources practices (e.g., deprovisioning, personnel screening).

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Response and recovery plans are tested.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Response plans (Incident Response and Business Continuity) and recovery plans (Incident Recovery and Disaster Recovery) are established, in place, and managed.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Effectiveness of protection technologies is shared.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Protection processes are improved.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Policy and regulations regarding the physical operating environment for organizational assets are met.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Backups of information are conducted, maintained, and tested.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Configuration change control processes are established and in place.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: A baseline configuration of information technology is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g., concept of least functionality).

nodes.key_activities: Communicate processing practices, provide transparency mechanisms
nodes.function_definition: Develop and implement appropriate activities to enable organizations and individuals to have a reliable understanding and engage in a dialogue about how data are processed and associated privacy risks
nodes.primary_focus: Transparency and communication about data processing

nodes.category_description: Individuals and organizations have reliable knowledge about data processing practices and associated privacy risks

nodes.subcategory_name: Individuals are provided with mitigation mechanisms (e.g., credit monitoring, consent withdrawal, data alteration or deletion) to address impacts of problematic data actions.
Impacted individuals and organizations are notified about a privacy breach or event.
Data provenance and lineage are maintained and can be accessed for review or transmission/disclosure.
Data corrections or deletions can be communicated to individuals or organizations (e.g., data sources) in the data processing ecosystem.
Records of data disclosures and sharing are maintained and can be accessed for review or transmission/disclosure.
System/product/service design enables data processing visibility.
Mechanisms for obtaining feedback from individuals (e.g., surveys or focus groups) about data processing and associated privacy risks are established and in place.

Mechanisms (e.g., notices, internal or public reports) for communicating data processing purposes, practices, associated privacy risks, and options for enabling individuals� data processing preferences and requests are established and in place.

nodes.category_description: Policies, processes, and procedures to increase transparency of data processing practices

nodes.subcategory_name: Roles and responsibilities (e.g., public relations) for communicating data processing purposes, practices, and associated privacy risks are established.
Transparency policies, processes, and procedures for communicating data processing purposes, practices, and associated privacy risks are established and in place.

nodes.key_activities: Manage data processing, enable individual control, implement disassociation
nodes.function_definition: Develop and implement appropriate activities to enable organizations or individuals to manage data with sufficient granularity to manage privacy risks

nodes.category_description: Data processing solutions increase disassociability consistent with the organizations risk strategy

nodes.subcategory_name: Attribute references are substituted for attribute values.
System or device configurations permit selective collection or disclosure of data elements.
Data are processed to limit the formulation of inferences about individuals� behavior or activities (e.g., data processing is decentralized, distributed architectures).
Data are processed to limit the identification of individuals (e.g., de-identification privacy techniques, tokenization).
Data are processed to limit observability and linkability (e.g., data actions take place on local devices, privacy-preserving cryptography).

nodes.category_description: Data are managed consistent with the organizations risk strategy to protect individuals privacy

nodes.subcategory_name: Stakeholder privacy preferences are included in algorithmic design objectives and outputs are evaluated against these preferences.
Technical measures implemented to manage data processing are tested and assessed.
Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy and incorporating the principle of data minimization.
Mechanisms for transmitting processing permissions and related data values with data elements are established and in place.
Data are transmitted using standardized formats.
Data are destroyed according to policy.
Data elements can be accessed for deletion.
Data elements can be accessed for alteration.
Data elements can be accessed for transmission or disclosure.
Data elements can be accessed for review.

nodes.category_description: Policies, processes, and procedures maintained and used to manage data processing
nodes.category_name: Data Processing Policies, Processes, and Procedures

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Processing Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Policies, processes, and procedures for authorizing data processing (e.g., organizational decisions, individual consent), revoking authorizations, and maintaining authorizations are established and in place.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Processing Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Policies, processes, and procedures for authorizing data processing (e.g., organizational decisions, individual consent), revoking authorizations, and maintaining authorizations are established and in place.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Processing Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Policies, processes, and procedures for authorizing data processing (e.g., organizational decisions, individual consent), revoking authorizations, and maintaining authorizations are established and in place.

nodes.subcategory_type: Data Processing Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.subcategory_name: Policies, processes, and procedures for authorizing data processing (e.g., organizational decisions, individual consent), revoking authorizations, and maintaining authorizations are established and in place.

nodes.key_activities: Establish policies, define risk tolerance, provide training
nodes.function_definition: Develop and implement the organizational governance structure to enable an ongoing understanding of the organizations risk management priorities that are informed by privacy risk

nodes.category_description: Policies, processes, and procedures for ongoing review of the organizations privacy posture

nodes.subcategory_name: Policies, processes, and procedures for receiving, tracking, and responding to complaints, concerns, and questions from individuals about organizational privacy practices are established and in place.
Policies, processes, and procedures incorporate lessons learned from problematic data actions.

Policies, processes, and procedures are established and in place to receive, analyze, and respond to problematic data actions disclosed to the organization from internal and external sources (e.g., internal discovery, privacy researchers, professional events).
Policies, processes, and procedures for communicating progress on managing privacy risks are established and in place.
Policies, processes, and procedures for assessing compliance with legal requirements and privacy policies are established and in place.
Privacy values, policies, and training are reviewed and any updates are communicated.

Privacy risk is re-evaluated on an ongoing basis and as key factors, including the organization�s business environment (e.g., introduction of new technologies), governance (e.g., legal obligations, risk tolerance), data processing, and systems/products/services change.

nodes.category_description: Workforce and third parties are provided privacy awareness education and training

nodes.subcategory_name: Third parties (e.g., service providers, customers, partners) understand their roles and responsibilities.
Privacy personnel understand their roles and responsibilities.
Senior executives understand their roles and responsibilities.
The workforce is informed and trained on its roles and responsibilities.

nodes.category_description: Organizations priorities, constraints, risk tolerances, and assumptions to support operational risk decisions

nodes.subcategory_name: The organization�s determination of risk tolerance is informed by its role(s) in the data processing ecosystem.
Organizational risk tolerance is determined and clearly expressed.
Risk management processes are established, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders.

nodes.category_description: Policies, processes, and procedures to manage and monitor regulatory, legal, risk, environmental, and operational requirements

nodes.subcategory_name: Governance and risk management policies, processes, and procedures address privacy risks.
Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding privacy are understood and managed.
Privacy roles and responsibilities are coordinated and aligned with third-party stakeholders (e.g., service providers, customers, partners).
Roles and responsibilities for the workforce are established with respect to privacy.
Processes to instill organizational privacy values within system/product/service development and operations are established and in place.

Organizational privacy values and policies (e.g., conditions on data processing such as data uses or retention periods, individuals� prerogatives with respect to data processing) are established and communicated.

nodes.key_activities: Inventory data processing, assess risks, understand ecosystem
nodes.function_definition: Develop the organizational understanding to manage privacy risk for individuals arising from data processing
nodes.primary_focus: Understanding data processing and privacy risks

nodes.category_description: Processes to identify, assess, and manage privacy risks within the data processing ecosystem

nodes.subcategory_name: Data processing ecosystem parties are routinely assessed using audits, test results, or other forms of evaluations to confirm they are meeting their contractual, interoperability framework, or other obligations.
Interoperability frameworks or similar multi-party approaches are used to manage data processing ecosystem privacy risks.
Contracts with data processing ecosystem parties are used to implement appropriate measures designed to meet the objectives of an organization�s privacy program.

Data processing ecosystem parties (e.g., service providers, customers, partners, product manufacturers, application developers) are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a privacy risk assessment process.
Data processing ecosystem risk management policies, processes, and procedures are identified, established, assessed, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders.

nodes.category_description: The organization understands the privacy risks to individuals and how such privacy risks may create follow-on impacts

nodes.subcategory_name: Risk responses are identified, prioritized, and implemented.
Problematic data actions, likelihoods, and impacts are used to determine and prioritize risk.
Potential problematic data actions and associated problems are identified.
Data analytic inputs and outputs are identified and evaluated for bias.

Contextual factors related to the systems/products/services and the data actions are identified (e.g., individuals� demographics and privacy interests or perceptions, data sensitivity and/or types, visibility of data processing to individuals and third parties).

nodes.category_description: The organizations mission, objectives, stakeholders, and activities are understood and prioritized

nodes.subcategory_name: Systems/products/services that support organizational priorities are identified and key requirements communicated.
Priorities for organizational mission, objectives, and activities are established and communicated.
The organization�s role(s) in the data processing ecosystem are identified and communicated.

nodes.category_description: Data processing by systems, products, or services is understood and informs the management of privacy risk

nodes.subcategory_name: Data processing is mapped, illustrating the data actions and associated data elements for systems/products/services, including components; roles of the component owners/operators; and interactions of individuals or third parties with the systems/products/services.
The data processing environment is identified (e.g., geographic location, internal, cloud, third parties).
Data elements within the data actions are inventoried.
The purposes for the data actions are inventoried.
Data actions of the systems/products/services are inventoried.
Categories of individuals (e.g., customers, employees or prospective employees, consumers) whose data are being processed are inventoried.

Owners or operators (e.g., the organization or third parties such as service providers, partners, customers, and developers) and their roles with respect to the systems/products/services and components (e.g., internal or external) that process data are inventoried.
Systems/products/services that process data are inventoried.
